awd_titl_txt: DMREF: Dynamic Control of 3-D Printed Hierarchical Soft Materials via Computation-Guided Molecular Design
awd_abstract_narration:
3-D printing enables the rapid creation of precisely shaped items for everyday use, from customizable, engineered items such as vehicle parts and manufacturing prototypes, to patient-specific medical devices like stents and prostheses. Through use of computer programmed instructions, this technology is currently capable of making uniform items with micrometer precision. 3-D printing is already a revolutionary technology, but still cannot create the truly advanced materials found in living systems that adapt and transform upon stimulation by altering structures across length scales. For example, chameleons change their color by adjusting their skin structure at nanometer length scales. This research seeks to significantly advance the frontier of 3-D printing by introducing the new on-the-fly dynamic capability of tuning material structures down to the nanoscale. This capability will be achieved by designing self-assembling materials, where the self-assembly can be controlled by precisely adjusting the stresses in the printing process. This approach will enable chameleon-skin-like materials capable of rapid color adaptation to be made. This interdisciplinary team brings together expertise on making materials, testing how these materials flow, and printing these materials. This is then combined with advanced molecular simulation to design and evaluate possible materials capable of meeting the criteria for controlled on-the-fly printing of nano-scale structures. These new materials will benefit society and the U.S. by adaptably printing new items with potential applications in camouflage, antireflection coatings, metamaterials, and displays. The research will also involve the training of students with broad expertise spanning chemistry, engineering, and physics, via both student mentorship and educational outreach to students underrepresented in STEM fields.

This research will use the stresses in out-of-equilibrium 3-D printing processes to 'dial-in' hierarchical structural features in printed structures. A class of candidate materials known as bottlebrush block copolymers can form nanometer structures that readily deform under an applied stress. Bottlebrush block copolymers are a promising materials platform because they possess a large molecular design space. The PIs will develop and implement a screening methodology to explore this design space and determine optimal bottlebrush block copolymers for hierarchical printable materials. A holistic approach to computer-driven design will combine scalable synthesis, large-scale simulation, and rheological characterization to systematically design polymer molecules to yield desired, flow-induced nano-structures. This design procedure will be implemented to optimize 3-D printed nanostructured materials 'on-the-fly', culminating in a proof-of-concept of 3-D printed materials with heterogeneous photonic (i.e. color) properties. Along with this broad goal, this research will address fundamental questions in developing new, scalable polymer chemistry, driven self-assembly, and the rheology of bottlebrush block copolymers.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
This goal of this DMREF project was to engineer brush-like molecules to exhibit tunable colors during a printing process. These bottlebrush molecules are highly tunable, both in terms of the length of a central backbone and the length of side-chains (that form the brush). The chemical composition of these side-chains on one end of the backbone are different than on the other, and thus solutions of these molecules will assemble into layers on nanometer length scales; these materials thus exhibit structural color, similar to how butterfly wings or chameleons get their vibrant colors. We were able to show that it is possible to tune solution printing processes to change this structural color on the fly (Figure 1).

Intellectual Merit: We developed a molecular understanding of this printing behavior through a combination of polymer synthesis, molecular simulation, and mechanical and x-ray characterization (Figure 2). Innovation in the area of polymer synthesis revolves around the use of automated flow-reactors to on-the-fly tune the length of side-chains, and thus molecular shape. Careful measurement and prediction of molecular weight distributions complemented this synthesis. These self-assembling molecules were characterized by both their response to mechanical force and their ability to scatter X-rays and neutrons. This yielded both a measurement of how solution conditions affect the width of layered structures, as well as an understanding of how these layers rearrange under the influence of strong shear flows. Finally, molecular simulation was able to predict how the branches in bottlebrush polymers gave rise to their molecular geometry, and consequently their self-assembly into layers that exhibit structural colors. Overall, this collaborative approach was able to establish a molecular design scheme spanning chemical synthesis to materials processing and application, with new insights to bottlebrush self-assembly at all relevant length scales.

Broader Impacts: This work has important ramifications in materials processing and discovery, providing a scheme for molecular-level materials design that integrates characterization, synthesis, and simulation to control nanoscale material properties on-the-fly. In addition, this project made significant contributions to the realization of automated synthesis, novel methods in rheology, and strategies for multi-scale simulations; this progress is broadly transferable to other areas of chemical engineering, materials science, chemistry, and other related areas.

This project also had significant impact on the training of the next generation of interdisciplinary scientists and engineers. Researchers were exposed to, and developed proficiency in, a wide variety of concepts from molecular simulation and theory, polymer synthesis, materials processing, and scattering and rheological characterization. This program played a role in training 9 graduate students, 1 postdoctoral researcher, and several undergraduate students. All team members participated in regular biweekly meetings, sharing research progress and relevant literature in group discussions, and nucleating direct collaboration between groups of students. These interactions culminated in most of the publications being multi-PI efforts, relying on the combined expertise of the PIs in this DMREF program. The participants in this program also contributed to a number of outreach efforts (Figure 3), including programs for underrepresented groups at the elementary and high school age groups, and a program to print face masks early in the COVID-19 pandemic.


Last Modified: 02/07/2022
Modified by: Charles E Sing
